i really hope this ends soon... the pandemic hasnt affected me with the disease factor quite as much as it has the lifestyle changes. i already had chronic depression and motivational issues, but i was doing really well before all of this... going out, seeing people, exercising frequently enough to be pretty good at walking uphill, anxiety was manageable...

but then all of this happened and i was told to do exactly what i was never supposed to do, the thing that was guarenteed to make my symptoms way worse: stay inside, don't see anyone.

it's been almost two years since this pandemic began, since i began self isolating. it was fun at first - i thought so, because i got to stay inside and play video games with my friends all day. but it gradually became a huge problem. my room became the messiest it has ever been, im deconditioned to the point where walking for five blocks can cause serious muscle strain or even make me vomit, im stuck in these incredibly unhelpful habits... my lifestyle has been absolutely destroyed by all of this. my support network almost completely dissolved. im borderline agoraphobic and its all because of these restrictions put in place that told me to do exactly what i should have never done to myself.

and im not an anti masker, or an anti vaccinator. i'm also not anti-lockdown or anti-covid anything. i believe this was the best thing to do for everybody, locking down had to happen, all of this did. i blame no one because there is no one to blame. the circumstances were incredibly unfortunate, and now i need to go through the difficult task of pulling myself back up from this pit of despair and deconditioning, the hard way. the support network i spent so long forming is gone, and now i need to make a new one from the ground up, because im alone now, besides my long distance partner and my occupational therapist, who is helping me currently.

i really do feel like im rotting in my own body. i've never been this unhealthy before. i've found myself mourning my health a lot recently. i used to be so much more able than this. things used to be better, i used to be better.

all i can really do every day is just hold on. just wait. just survive. keep living... that's me, doing my best, just staying alive despite the absolute misery i'm in

i've had some friends get covid, but none have passed away thankfully. my significant other got it, and it did leave her with some lung damage, but shes okay. other friends got omicron and are generally okay too. my grandma got it ... thank god she lived, although she might not have much longer with the long lasting damage it left her with.

too many people had to die from this, and there are other instances of collateral damage that this pandemic has caused. i hope my story is illuminating somehow. sorry for the wall of text, i guess i just needed to vent. this pandemic has impacted a lot of us in different ways.

Books worth of criticism are invited by this video.
An example: ACE-2 receptors are profuse in endothelial cells- the entirety of inward-facing vascular tissue. This virus enters through a critical component, then of the angiotensin-renin system, which works to change blood pressure in response to numerous specific stressors. Do NOT expect "equally possible" to correlate remotely or at all with equally probable. Since the virus is most debilitating to elders and those who have compromised their health through behaviors influencing their cardiac, vascular, respiratory, immune, and related systems and organs, it COULD, as a signifciantly strong PROBABILITY, affect us in evolutionary pressure toward r-selection.
Thus endemicity is a danger, rather than the "whoopee! we all get it so-what" attitude visible in the presumptions of the presenters.
Nearly 8 BILLION hosts of a species can easily be statistically shown to nullify evolutionary pressure to become less virulent (and virulent DIFFERS from Transmissible.. as SARS-2 will show you. Its evolved entry point is inherently dangerously virulent, if you did not comprehend this from my example). A species that refuses to change its density AND its herding behaviors is in for a longer, meaner time, until it is reduced in overconnectivity or host population size. Only if the latter is vastly reduced can you expect a reasonable likelihood of reduction in virulence.
Other dangerously virulent viruses are not a problem SOLELY because of diminished transmissiblity. THe hantavirus[es] case in point. Other cellular parasites far larger than viruses, like malaria, are now and have overcome resistance to drugs, changed in response to immune adaptations, and "endemic" kill at much higher rates than COVID. So, do NOT suggest that diminution of virulence is associated with endemicity.

One of the likely incubators of the Omicron variant is rodents, those associated with humans. this INCREASES the likelihood of continuing variation, and by this i do NOT mean "like the flu." Influenza repeats and repeats because humans refuse to engage in behaviors that end it.
THey don't have that luxury with viruses using ACE-2 receptor entry. Proteins used for certain physiological purposes are more conserved, and the ACE-2 receptor proteins of mustelids, some other carnivores, and omnivores, as this one is, offer larger host interactions and populations.

Until human populations are significantly reduced worldwide, this virus will be here, always taking effective shapes to make itself from us.
The Omicron variant binds more firmly to ACE-2 receptors than previous variants.
Yes, we DO understand how and where to attack its traits to stimulate our immune response - but Canadian truckers and US republicans desire to die rather than be inoculated. Polio, a fecal-oral and oral-oral virus was knocked out only because people chose NOT to die rather than be vaccinated.

What we MAY be looking at will be sympatric speciation in response to virus - but humans being the armed haters they are, this will be veery possibly one tie in which communicable disease leads to violent war, rather then, incubateed in Kansas/Nebraska pig farms, as the so-called "Spanish" flu was, spread by mass human movement to Europe to make war.
The antithought occurring in much of the world is precisely due to the stressor effects of overpopulation and overdensity. Our medieval response to this virus IS a result of overpopulation and its inescapable stress.

This may not be very scientific, but I was wondering if you guys could respond/research the reasons people are not getting vaccinated and debunk or explain them? I know that's the point of this video but I feel like calling out the bizarre conspiracies and explaining the evidence would not only make great content but would be very informative.

3:53. In my mind, it's not enough to claim that delta is special because it outpaces the body's immune response. If I'm not mistaken, any time one starts to show symptoms of a cold, it's because the germs are outpacing the initial immune response. So, every "cold" that a person has ever caught is the result of the germs outpacing the initial immune response.

From what I understand, when germs get in the body, the germs meet the "first line" of defense. If the first line succeeds in fighting off the invasion, then the battle is won and the host shows no symptoms. This is why one can get surface cuts and often not show symptoms of infection. This is also why sometimes (not always,) people can eat food and drink of questionable quality and be perfectly fine. There probably was contagion involved, but the first line of defense fought off the invasion.

However, should the disease outpace the first line of defense, then the body starts to show symptoms. This is because the body's full immune response has to be specially tailored to fight the invading disease. This takes time. So, unless the body knows what it's dealing with (aka, the body has immunity,) then disease multiplies quickly.

Once the body figures out how to combat the disease, then it's a race against time for the body. The disease has multiplied, and the body must deploy its solution before it becomes overwhelmed by the disease and the host dies. This is why people have cold symptoms. The symptoms are signs of the battle going on in the body.

So, diseases that outpace the body's initial immune response are common.

By extension, this is why people have immunity. When the body has immunity to a disease, then the body already knows how to combat the disease during the initial stages of infection. So, if the body is immune, then there is no "learning period." Instead, the body's immune response quickly ramps up to full during the initial stages of infection. As a result, the disease should get wiped out quickly, so the host never shows symptoms, or may show minor symptoms.

If, however, the claim is that delta outpaces the body's full immune response (what comes after the first wave,) then delta should have a much higher mortality rate than the mortality rate that other COVID strains. (I'm talking rates statistically more significant than 7% mortality. Think at least 50% or greater.) This is because, if the claim were true, then delta would outpace the body's initial response, then continue to outpace the body's full immune response, so the body wouldn't be able to "catch up" with the disease. As a result, patients who catch the delta variant should almost always get worse (never better) until they die.

6:07. I believe this is partially true. I believe that if the whole world got vaccinated, then the current strain of COVID would die out, in much a similar way that smallpox was irradicated. However, I believe that the coronavirus is zoonotic. In other words, it jumps the gap between animals and humans. This means that even if the current strain of coronavirus is wiped out in all humans, it would still gestate and mutate in animals, then jump the gap to humans again. And, when it does, I believe it has a pretty good chance of attacking the body in a new way. This would mean that the body would probably not be immune to the new strain of coronavirus, even if it were immune to the previous strain of coronavirus.

This is the reason why people need to get new flu vaccines every year. The flu is zoonotic, and frequently a new strain of flu jumps the gap between animals and humans. When it does, the previous year's vaccine usually does not work against the new strain of the virus, thus it requires a new vaccine.

6:13. I do not agree. If it were true that getting vaccinated against a previous strain of a virus could protect the body against new strains of a virus, then getting a certain amount of flu vaccines should protect the body against all future forms of the flu virus. This would mean that a middle aged man, who got vaccinated against flu every year since say... high school, should have taken 10+ flu vaccines in their lifetime. Does this make them immune to all future flu variants? I honestly don't know, but my guess is, no.

Honestly, I think the COVID pandemic will end when people start questioning some of the scientific claims behind it. One of the big ones in my mind is the idea that this disease cannot be tracked. I believe this is the bit of information that is driving everyone's response. The claim is that COVID (or the recent strains of COVID, as SARS is a Coronavirus which was tracked and contained within a few months, but I digress) is unlike every disease that has come before and cannot be tracked.

If I understand correctly, this was based on the idea that the disease has a "gestation period" of up to two weeks, therefore anyone in the incubation period could spread the disease. Although I believe that people in the incubation period could spread the disease, this argument by itself is not an adequate explanation for the claim. Most diseases have a gestation period and can be tracked. This includes SARS, which has a similar gestation period, yet it can and was tracked and was contained.

I have also heard the claim that this might (emphasis on might) be true because of a higher than usual amount of germs in the upper respiratory tract, which makes better sense, but if that's true then why wasn't that given to us at the start?

In any case, because of the claim that this disease cannot be tracked, then it is asserted that anyone could have it and anyone could spread it even if they exhibit no symptoms. Therefore, the claim is that tracking the disease is useless. Therefore, the claim is that the only defense against it is to get tested, get vaccinated, and practice social distancing.

This also the claim used to justify why symptoms are supposedly not a good sign to know if one is infected and spreading COVID or not. The claim is that asymptomatic people could spread it, so coughing and sneezing are not required to spread the virus.

Somehow, I'm not convinced. This disease is so unlike every single disease that came before it, including diseases within the same family of coronavirus, that it cannot be tracked? I am very skeptical of this claim.

"Coronaviruses displayed the marked seasonality typical of other respiratory viruses, with high detection frequencies in winter months but few or no detections in the summer (Fig. 2). The exception was HCoV-229E, which was detectable primarily in the winter of the second year of the study and sporadically through the third year of study." Use a search engine and you'll find the citation.

Your analysis is missing the point and the fact that R0<1 as a permanent feature of a seasonal virus doesn't really make sense. In other words.... A criteria of R0<1 is only temporarily achievable. If that is the goal, we will never achieve a permanent "end-of-SARS-CoV-2" state. You have described an unattainable condition.

I also dispute your sleight-of-hand with regard to prophylaxis. "Makes you a bit less sick" is a world apart from "helps you to not be part of the problem with regard pathogenicity of the virus." Just the opposite when it comes to "leaky" vaccines. Look up Marek's disease in chickens and tell me that interventions made chickens less likely to contribute to the problem of deadliness/spread/pathogenicity. What seems to you to be a logical extension is actually a factual contradiction.

Your 6 different paths are all one path with different management strategies. The virus will be endemic, it will continue to circulate, it will propagate in seasonal waves, it will be most dangerous in the immunocompromised (sick & elderly) and naive populations (babies), it will not be a great threat to the vast majority of people with prior exposure.

You talk out of both sides of your mouth on t-cell immunity issue. No amount of vaccination or level of t-cell immunity will provide 100% lifelong immunity, but the t-cell immunity will be "good enough" to prevent severe infection in most people upon re-exposure, most of the time--enough so as to not be able to differentiate between this virus and other endemic viruses. As with the other coronaviruses, there will be little to no value in vaccinating non-naive populations and there exists a danger of t cell exhaustion with continual boosters.

The only thing I can rule out is a vaccine providing lifetime immunity. You will need to provide even a theoretical basis for how that could even be possible. If the pathogen itself cannot give lifetime immunity, by what mechanism would an attenuated, weakened, incomplete viral analog do so? Perhaps if you inserted the genes into the body and somehow had the body continuously produce viral protein, but that would lead to all kinds of foreseeable autoimmune conditions. And for what?

When is the COVID pandemic going to end? So many people have been comparing the Spanish flu to SARS-CoV-2. For example, the Spanish Flu took place over two years, between 1918 to 1920, and consisted of four waves, so here we are, almost two years later, and there have been four waves, so it'll end in 2022? Right? Right? Today, we're going to break down how this all might end, with specific predictions based on expert opinions, past virus trajectories, and up-to-date research and models. Let's go.

First off, a reminder: that this novel coronavirus carries its genetic info as RNA, not DNA, and is considered an intracellular parasite, which is a fancy way of saying it can only reproduce within cells. So SARS-CoV-2 may think she's "that girl", but it's like, "Are you even alive? Call me when you have your own cells or a metabolism, hon?" Although maybe we shouldn't be making fun of her, 'cause currently she's doing a great job infecting us all.

Even though the flu is also an RNA virus, it is different than the current RNA coronavirus that we are all talking about. So to understand what is going to happen to us in the future, it's also worth looking at the coronaviruses or colds that infect all of us each year. A new Genius study went back to look at blood samples over multiple decades for the seasonal coronavirus 229E, because this virus is able to infect people repeatedly throughout their lives. But what they realized, through the blood samples, was that individuals in the '80s had different immune markers than those in the '90s, and even moreso from those in the 2000s. This makes researchers think Coronavirus 229E might also be mutating throughout these decades. That's maybe what's causing reinfection -- it's not just fading immune response. So the big question is when will SARS-CoV-2 virus join the other four coronaviruses that circulate throughout populations and cause relatively mild colds -- how does that happen? Now THAT is the big question.

On the one hand, it could become endemic, meaning infections stabilize without these unexpected spikes. That would require a low reproduction number, like R1. Meaning an infected person is likely to infect only one other person -- not like this Omicron variant, which is making graphs of COVID cases look like a comedic joke, straight line up. On the other hand, SARS-CoV-2 could become something more threatening, like a bad flu or something even worse. It's a myth to say that viruses only evolve to become more mild, which is a narrative that keeps getting pushed. It's possible, but the reality is far more complex. The RNA inside is a blueprint that needs to get its genetic material into the cytoplasm of your cells, then the ribosome starts reading the blueprint three nucleic acids at a time, then it strings them together and creates the protein. But, occasionally, the wrong nucleic acid will get added to the chain. This can sometimes lead to changes, making an offspring virus different from its parent. And these random changes can sometimes be advantageous to the virus. Early genome sequencing of the SARS-CoV-2 virus showed that it was picking up around two single-letter mutations per month.

There are two importants to think about how mutations affect the virus that we are currently all freeing from. One is its transmissibility. Like mutations that make it replicate faster, or make it more contagious to others. And, two is its ability to evade immune response. Like mutations in the spike proteins that make it sneak past our immune system. Gamma and Beta had a slew of mutations in the fame-fame spike protein we're all talking about that made it bind more easily to Ace2 receptors in your body, and that made it more easily absorbed into your cells, meaning, boom, it's more transmissible. It's more likely to gain these effective mutations the longer it replicates in a host. So the longer you are sick, the more likely these mutations can happen. This is why these mutations are more likely to happen in people who are not vaccinated, or in people who are immunocompromised.

King Delta, I then divine in spring 2021, was 60% more transmissible than any other strain before, because the mutations that researchers think caused it to replicate faster in the airwys of infected individuals, outpacing the initial immune response, especially again in those unvaccinated. So, boom, you have increased transmissibility and evading immune response. Delta is more transmissible than the current flus we deal with, or any of those four common colds that we talked about earlier, but it's less transmissible than measles and polio. It's also nice to know that this transmissibility of a virus can just increase forever. We're dealing with the laws of nature, and there are certain parameters on our biology. The virus needs to toy with the ability to replicate in thine airways and lungs, but also with making sure we're not so sick - it wants us to be out there and spreading it, it doesn't want us to be sick at home in bed, not able to move. The virus wants to infect my family. And when we say 'want' here, a gentle reminder that the virus isn't sentient and doesn't consciously want these things. It's just that the more optimal versions of the virus will spread more effectively, out-competing other variants that might be too deadly or not transmissible enough.

Omicron came out of left field, like, she's stomped on the scene. This baby has 30 mutations in the spike protein and has involved to infect people who are immune through vaccination or previous infection to Delta. But as gains in transmissibility slow, it needs to figure out ways to continue to overcome immune responses, which is probably what's happening right now. Experiments and lab sequencing of variants circulating right now have identified a bunch of mutations in spike proteins that weaken your body's immune response which has been boosted by vaccination or prior infection. But the important thing that we do know is that vaccines continue to protect against severe disease. Your T-cell-mediated immunity created by the mRNA vaccine is a huge step in speeding up and overcoming this pandemic, and that's why getting the world vaccinated is so important. That doesn't mean that it'll just go away overnight, but being vaccinated continues to make you more resilient to any mutations in SARS-CoV-2 over time, as it's proven to make you less sick. Perhaps even more important is that it allows you to not contribute to the problem of it becoming even more transmissible or evading immunity. So continued vaccination can build up a wall of immunity that the virus can no longer overcome. Essentially - if the whole world was suddenly vaccinated at once - the overall T-cell-mediated immunity would be high enough to help us be more resilient to any upcoming changes of the virus, and as a result, it wouldn't be able to spread as fast and likely become more endemic as easily.

Of now, there are six scenarios that experts think about our future for COVID.

One, we do a better job vaccinating the world, the overall T-cell immunity of humanity increases, making the virus more likely to be endemic, resulting in outbreaks and epidemics of varying sizes, like other respiratory infections we already have, more likely the current coronaviruses and flu we all deal with.

Two, though considered endemic, we have small changes in the spike proteins that open up parts of society to re-infection. The virus continues to evolve, but we combat waning immune responses with annual vaccines, like the flu shot, and the only people who are highly susceptible are those who are unvaccinated, and children borne without immunity.

Three, this one's good, but not likely - we invent a vaccine like the measles vaccine that offers lifetime protection, and the only people who are susceptible are newborn kids.

Four, it ends up like respiratory syncytial virus, meaning it's around, like maybe forever, but in the far future, most people get infected in the first two years of life. It is mild for most kids but it does cause high hospitalization rates over all for infants. As it spreads or evolves, adults have mild symptoms due to their exposure they already had as a kid.

Five, it ends up like influenza-A, the little bugger that drives global flu each year. This baby has rapid evolution and spreads with new variants that are able to escape the immunity elicited by past strains. This results in seasonal epidemics largely spread by adults, who can still have severe illness. Like the flu vaccine, our annual coronavirus vaccine will decrease transmissibility and decrease severe disease, but the quick mutation means that these vaccines aren't always properly designed for the specific strains of the year, and will need to continually be updated.

Six, it ends up like influenza-B -- evolves more slowly, and is driven largely by infection in children, who have less immunity than adults, who are more immune from prior infection and vaccines. It's important to remember that how quickly SARS-CoV-2 evolves in relation to immune response will continually explain how often we need to be updating these vaccines.

Detrimental
Neutral
Beneficial

I've had COVID twice and I am fully vaccinated and boosted. What appears to be happening is exactly what is happening. No need to overcomplicate or spin around an already impossible situation. Coronaviruses among other flu-like viruses (including common human coronaviruses) have been notorious for not triggering any kind of long term immunity...this has been known for decades now. That is why we can't eradicate Flu, Rhino, RSV, Metapneumo, Adeno, etc. They only trigger short term immunity and the strains quickly mutate to beat the immune system protections.

Vaccines and eradication strategies work perfectly with viruses that trigger lifelong or very long term immunity and that mutate very slowly. What the data is showing is that COVID vaccines add a bit of protection for severe symptoms in the most vulnerable individuals, but fail to stop transmission or symptoms. The virus WILL SPREAD no matter what. Even with a booster by the 3rd month you have a 50/50 chance of getting it if you are exposed, by the 4th month you are already on the losing side of that battle (around 40% effectivity) according to the latest studies in UK. It is simply unsustainable to vaccinate billions of people every 2 or 3 months.

For more evidence of the glitch see that we have the highest amount of individuals fully vaccinated since the pandemic started and the virus is now spreading at its quickest pace so far. The Omicron wave 7-day average for deaths is overtaking the Delta deaths numbers even when we are now conveniently rethinking who should qualify as "dying of COVID" vs "dying with COVID"...we already know that 2021 was a deadlier year than 2020. The evidence is all around. We can only cross our fingers with future trends and mutations, but I would be careful to suggest we have COVID by the throat...the virus is nowhere near finished mutating.

If you are not afraid of getting sick and you are in reasonable health...move on with your life, there is little we can do to actually stop the virus, it is mostly placebos and social theater. If you are afraid of the virus and/or you are in poor health ...brace yourself and take good care of yourself (vaccines, prevention, and prompt initiation of therapeutics if you get infected). Unfortunately nobody can stop this and it is going to go on for a very long time.

The reason that its not a myth that "viruses evolve to become less lethal" is directly due to the fact that more lethality equates to death/immobilization, which usually means that that particular lethal variant becomes less likely to spread because the hosts are too sick or too dead to transmit to another host. It is just natural selection. E.g Ebola a virus in Central Africa is so lethal (95% mortality) that it barely spreads any further than the Congo. As for that reason, that particular virus has never become a full on pandemic despite being highly transmissible.

He waited several months before taking a third booster dose on Monday, November 8.

Within days Keating’s health deteriorated and he was no longer able to work due to shortness of breath.

“Tuesday and Wednesday he was fine,” described Keating’s mother, Cayleen, “but Thursday morning — 72 hours after the booster — he called and said he had a sore throat.”

The Defender’s Megan Redshaw reports on how the family had no indications Keating’s heart would soon fail, and believed he was experiencing mild side effects.

Cayleen made her son some hot apple cider and he took throat lozenges and went to work, but within two hours he called her to pick him up because he was so fatigued he couldn’t work.

When Cayleen asked him what was wrong, Joseph told her he had some muscle soreness, exhaustion and a sore throat.

[…] Joseph slept through Thursday. On Friday morning, he told his mother he would have to call into work again because he was too exhausted to go in. Cayleen visited Joseph and said he appeared to be normal, other than fatigue and muscle soreness.

“He wasn’t really acting sick, just exhausted,” she said.

Cayleen, a critical care nurse of 35 years, took her son’s vitals and noted his temperature was up to 100.2 and his heart rate was elevated to 112. She thought it was related to the fever, so she gave him Tylenol.

Later that day, Joseph texted his mother that his fever was down. By 4:30 p.m., his oxygen was at 100%, but his heart rate was still elevated.

Joseph’s father, William, visited his son around 5 p.m. and they had dinner. William left at 6 p.m. Two hours later their son was dead.

The autopsy report notes Keating’s Apple Watch recorded an extremely high heart rate the morning of his death:

“His Apple watch recorded no cardia activity after 1959 hours. He did not respond to a text at 2100 hours. On November 13th he did not text his mother in the morning as he usually did and his family subsequently found him deceased in his recliner.”

A death certificate issued by the State of South Dakota and obtained by the Defender lists Keating’s cause of death from “multifocal myocarditis involving the left ventricle and septum,” with a second cause of death listed as “Recent Pfizer Covid-19 booster vaccine.”

I love your content and I’m commenting this to hopefully be educational:
Please don’t propagate the ideia that the virus “wants” anything. I graduated in biology and I met my best friend in uni and she is a virology phd student (at Brock University, her name is Garrido you can search her. She had to pause her research due to the fact that her lab is one of few in canada with the clearance to work with the virus) and when talking about this she said that this is a flawed logic concept. The virus doesn’t “want” anything but to replicate, it has no consciousness or will. The idea that virus evolution is correlated with “not making us too sick we die” is not correct. Once you’re infected you have the ability to pass it on, and you do (unless you take active measures to stop it), if you die or not doesn’t “matter” to the virus because it already did its biological job of replicating.
I personally also think it’s not biologically correct to use want and will in evolutionary biology, up until modern civilization (which makes up less than 1% of human history) there was no willful selection of anything, like you guys stated with mutations: it was all random and it still is.
Just because we humans have the ability to assign positive or negative evolutionary value to things now, it doesn’t mean they exist with a “conscious” direction.
I do love your content and how you guys are great at explaining things! I think it seems easier to understand to others this idea of things wanting and willing since society is so essentialist, and I don’t think it’s necessary.

I have to say this glosses over UPPER vs LOWER respiratory infection. The main reason Omicron is so much more transmissible than Delta is because it infects (& reproduces in) the UPPER airways (like the throat), which increases the amount of viral material that is spread around when coughing. In contrast, Delta infected the LOWER airways more, making it less transmissible but more deadly. So, yes, it is actually true that transmissibility is USUALLY inverse to lethality.

The terminology you guys are using isn't quite correct. I don't think transmissibility means what you think it means or were led to think. The same goes for strain. Granted transmissibility is defined differently by virologists and epidemiologist so that can get confusing. Regardless, the epidemiological definition (which is what many have relied on) does not provide sufficient evidence for an intrinsic change in the virus biology resulting in increased transmission. We cannot discern between biology, human behaviour, environmental factors, etc. with just a reproductive number. Sure, omicron does appear to be more immune evasive but that does not equal increased transmissibility. A recent preprint out of Denmark evidences this well by showing that there is no difference in odds between unvaccinated people of getting either Delta and Omicron, but there is a difference among vaccinated people, where vaccinated people had a higher odds of being infected by Omicron than Delta. I understand that some studies show better binding to ACE-II receptors, but they should be interpreted with caution, because while they provide clues, they cannot be so simply generalized to humans as whole, complex beings. It also doesn't necessarily equate to more transmissibility.
We are seeing increased spread driven by an increased overall fitness of the virus largely driven by immune evasion in addition to changes in human behaviour and contraction of neutralizing antibodies.
As always, I admire your sci comm videos, but I think it needs more nuance and fact-checking. I totally agree with you, though, we need to get the whole world access to these vaccines!

This is an excellent introductory video that brings up a lot of factors that the average person might not be considering. However, obviously it isn't a complete picture.

For one thing, it's important to understand the unique immune response pathway of a SARS-COV-2 infection. One reason it's generally not appropriate to compare this virus to other respiratory viruses is because it has the ability to mess with your innate immune response, which usually kicks in pretty quickly after infection. Infected immune cells express certain key molecules less: molecules responsible for recruiting the adaptive immune system. This is why you can be infectious without having symptoms: there is a period of potentially several days where the virus is replicating rapidly without immune intervention.

Without getting too far into the weeds, this one aspect of SARS-COV-2 infection is a hugely important distinction that makes it completely unlike previous pandemics. It makes a lifetime vaccine all but impossible. It also makes it easier for the virus to continue to spread and mutate even within a largely immunized population. Vaccinated people would be much less likely to see severe illness, but that could still spread it, allowing it to continue to mutate and evolve to become unrecognizable to prior immunity. And because of the lack of lasting immunity, the virus has a lot more "options" for how to mutate.

So without COVID-zero strategies, it seems much more likely that we'll see a constant stream of new variants, some of which are less harmful, some of which are more. It won't be relegated to outbreaks like the flu, but rather a continuous cycle of waves.

Again, this is only if we continue to fail at implementing COVID-zero strategies. The less widespread this virus is, the smaller the chance of a new variant emerging that already has a global foothold.

A mutation that provides vaccine resistance will not be useful in an unvaccinated individual unless it provides other benefits as well. Therefore it is reasonable to expect vaccine resistant strains to appear more quickly in a highly vaccinated population. The Omicron variant took a completely different route and spread through mice before jumping back to the human population where the mouse appropriate mutations also happened to sidestep our immunity.

In other words, vaccines will not stop this virus and I think it's better to just focus on vaccinating people in risk groups rather than trying to push it to every single person on the entire planet. The vaccines haven't even been able to stop Delta in places with a 97-100% vaccination rate and Omicron is 3-5 times as contagious, thus it's better to just focus on decreasing hospitalizations to levels that the healthcare systems can handle. Most who have died have had comorbidities and more than 95% of them have been older than 50. Hospitalizations follow a similar pattern with around 90% being people over 40 (at least in my country). For healthy people and especially younger people it really isn't much of a threat, and with Omicron it looks like the flu is actually much worse.

I'm an elementary school teacher and believe I unknowingly contracted Covid from one of my students shortly after my school made masking optional. I went to my family doctor with my only initial symptom being a sore throat and figured I had strep. My doctor asked if I'd been fully vaccinated and boosted, which I had been. She tested me for strep and it came back negative. I was prescribed allergy medicine and antibiotics and sent home. I was not tested for Covid-19. Luckily, I was on a school break for 9 days and was not in close contact with people outside of my household. The following week my mother started off with congestion and a fever and shortly after lost her sense of smell and taste. She tested positive for Covid-19 and since she isn't in close contact with many other people and I was just sick, I think I was the person who gave it to her. She changed nothing about her daily life around my father- they still shared a bed and everything. He did not show any symptoms whatsoever. Now, nearly two months later, he has symptoms very similar to what I had- sore throat, hoarse voice, cough. He just tested positive for Covid-19. My question is: How did he not get sick immediately after my mother? Could he have contracted it and been asymptomatic the first time and now caught a different strand? Could he be more susceptible to one of the strands over another?
I don't know if this is useful information, but he is 72 years old and his blood type is O negative.

MAJOR ERROR at 2:30
You have mistaken translation errors for transcription errors. Translation is when RNA is turned into proteins; transcription is when the viral RNA is copied into viral RNA for the next viral "generation".

While a translation error may result in a protein acting slightly differently, you are talking about a single protein at a time, and the errors would appear randomly (not completely, but effectively) on the proteins. Each viral sheath will have several copies of the protein, so a few point mutations is not likely to have much effect on the viral transmissibility or virulence. More importantly, these changes will not be carried forward!

To have a change in the virus that carries from one generation to the next; to form a new viral strain, the RNA sequence itself must change. This is transcription, it is not done in the ribosome.

This is pretty basic cellular biology. Shame on you.
